The Panthers of Jones Elementary in Bryan ISD commemorated 9-11 today by recreating the "Survivor Tree" that survived the Sept. 11 devastation at Ground Zero in New York.
---
Jones students wrote messages of hope on leaves & then used them to create their own survivor tree. They learned about preserving through struggle and the rebirth that can await afterward, much like the & renewal of the tree.
---
Before & after creating the tree, students participated in moments of silent flag waving at the exact time the towers hit the twin towers in 2001. (8:46 a.m. & 9:03 a.m.)

Thank you to everyone involved for remembering 9-11 in such a thought-provoking & impactful way.

#BryanProud

Eligible families should have received the application link from their school. Eligible families that received SNAP benefits for March have already received P-EBT benefits and do not have to apply. Visit hhs.texas.gov/pebt to learn more about P-EBT. If you did not receive an application link or if you need help filling out the P-EBT application, please contact the P-EBT Call Center at 833-613-6220. The public charge rule does not apply to P-EBT benefits.

On June 19, 1865, Union Army General Gordon Granger read federal orders in Galveston, Texas, that all slaves in Texas are free, two years after the Emancipation Proclamation. Texas was the first state to declare Juneteenth a holiday in 1980.

Due to COVID-19, many of the Brazos Valley‚Äôs annual parades & events have been canceled or modified. The graphic below outlines a couple of ways you can still safely celebrate in our community.

post_text: Last week, The GiveJoy Foundation delivered 200 boxes of food called "JoyBoxes" to Rayburn Intermediate School in Bryan ISD! The purpose fo the delivery was to get healthy food into classrooms, so teachers did not have to pay so much out-of-pocket to give students their snacks. Rayburn held a contest for students to design the boxes. GiveJoy chose five winners that each received $100 gift cards for their designs. #Wow #ThankYou #TellTheStory
